metadata.synopsis: A childhood incident has convinced Faith Corvatch (Marisa Tomei) that her true love is a guy named "Damon Bradley," but she has yet to meet him. Preparing to settle down and marry a foot doctor, Faith impulsively flies to Venice when it seems that she may be able to finally encounter the man of her dreams. Instead, she meets the charming Peter Wright (Robert Downey Jr.). But can they fall in love if she still believes that she is intended to be with someone else?

reviews: ...an appealingly romantic premise that's employed to rather hit-and-miss effect by Jewison...
It's only ostensibly about men; the real focus is on the friendship between two women, as well as the ways in which their support system helps them get past tribulations.
Moonstruck director Norman Jewison successfully mines the same territory with this delicious "Cinderella Italian-style" romantic comedy.
Hunt plays the Eve Arden role of Tomei's wisecracking pal to perfection, making her the single best reason to see the movie.
"Only You" plays more like a pleasant travelogue than an involving film.
[D]espite the lovely Italian locales and a relatively appealing cast, the film is far too cloying for all but the most sentimental tastes.

If it seems implausible that a young woman on a teacher's salary would be able to sport designer clothes and stay in posh pensiones all over Italy, well, who is a reviewer to quibble with ``destino''?
Movies like Only You and its obvious model, Sleepless in Seattle, are less true romances than they are collections of romantic signifiers.
Jewison knows exactly where the laugh and welling-up buttons are that will hook the audience into this middle-class fairy-tale-come-true, and has smartly cast it with engaging personalities.

Jewison's romantic comedy is a well-made fluff, a handsome trifle that's easily watched and just as easily forgettable; a pale effort compared to Jewison's Moon Struck, and Marisa Tomei is really not a romantic lead.
Even so, the ravishing visuals, some swooning love songs, and the strains of Verdi should see you through to the predictably moist ending.
One of those movies that evaporates from memory the moment you leave the theater.
Too schmaltzy by half, and Downey and Tomei just never click.
Mr. Jewison takes a voluptuously cornball approach to this story. And the story itself, by Diane Drake, is actually rather sweet.
Unfair but true, not so much good
